abstract.para: This file provides documentation for file 90BOHYPO.DAT, an ASCII file that contains final data for hyporheic nutrients. Samples were collected from pools and riffles in both the control and fertilized reaches of the Kuparuk River.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Kuparuk River Control: Riffles at 0.3 km. Fertilized: Riffles at 1.5, 2, and 3 km.

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: June 97 DATA FILE ENTERED BY: Karie Slavik DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: Karie Slavik DATE: 03Sept97

para.literalLayout: Hyporheic sampling wells were fabricated from lengths of 1/8 in. stainless steel (SS) tubing taped along 6 ft lengths of 1/2 in. rebar. The bottom end of the SS was open but covered with several layers of PVC window screen to prevent clogging. The top end of the SS was attached to a 1/8 in. Swagelok to a 1/8 in. female NPT fitting. This, in turn, was attached to a 1/8 in. male NPT to 1/8 in. I.D. plastic hose barb. A two-inch length of 1/8 in. I.D. X 1/16 in. wall Tygon tubing attached tightly to the plastic hose barb fitting. The sampling port, a three-way Pharmaseal stopcock, was inserted into the end of the plastic tubing. This assembly ensured an air-tight sampling port. Samplers were inserted into the streambed by initially forcing a steel pry bar into the cobbles to the deepest depth allowed, usually 30-60 cm. The pry bar was carefully removed, and immediately replaced with the sampler. The samplers were allowed to settle for two weeks prior to sampling. Wells were sampled with 60 cc B.D. syringes. Initially purging each sampler was purged by withdrawing 10-20 ml of water slowly from the well. This water was discarded and 60 ml of fresh water was withdrawn and immediately filtered with disposable 0.45 um, 25 mm diameter syringe filters into acid-washed 125 ml polypropylene bottles. The filter was rinsed with 10 ml of sample prior to collection of sample. If the well water contained excessive sediment, the sample was allowed to settle in the syringe for 1 to 2 minutes. Filtered samples were refrigerated at Toolik Camp until nutrient analysis could be completed on the autoanalyzer.

Notes: These data should not be released to any party without the written permission of William B. Bowden. Some data are unavailable at this time. There was a problem with the file transfer between the Technicon Autoanalyzer and the spreadsheet. Sample dates and locations were scrambled and can not deciphered. The data reported here are correct. (11) VARIABLE DESCRIPTIONS: Precis. Coded? Missing Variable Variable description Units (Y/N) Values
SITE site of measurement y D/D distance from 1984 dripper 0.05 km n DATE date ddmmyy n LOCATION location (CONTROL, +P) n SUBSITE typically POOL or RIFFLE n WELLID Identification of well n WELLTYPE SS or PVC n WELLZ Depth of well in streambed cm n NO3 NO3 Concentration umoles/liter n . NH4 NH4 Concentration umoles/liter n . PO4 PO4 Concentration umoles/liter n .
Calculations: Concentrations derived from linear regressions of absorbance versus known standards.
